results.title: One man's road
results.creator_credit: Robert Kingsbury, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The life of an Aborigine and his family in reserves, country situations and Sydney. Clive and Ida Williams recall the disadvantages typical of most Aborigines’ lives in New South Wales which prevent full participation in society, and their successful assimilation in the city.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Kingsbury, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.description: The life of an Aborigine and his family in reserves, country situations and Sydney. Clive and Ida Williams recall the disadvantages typical of most Aborigines’ lives in New South Wales which prevent full participation in society, and their successful assimilation in the city.

results.title: A Hundred-Odd Years From Now
results.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Australian Dried Fruits Association and Film House Company
results.brief_description: An advertising film with a difference: Into a strange computerised future where women “run things” by controlling huge colourful computers that go bleep booble bob bob ping etc, comes Yockoo, the boy from the bush, with his satchel of dried fruits. Slowly the women overcome their cold, futuristic ways in light of Yockoo’s size, shape and overall manliness. Eventually they unearth their deep feminine sexuality and cook Yockoo a feast of dried fruit dishes using cooking utensils from their local museum. Music by Frank Smith, Photographed by Lars Gundlach, Written and designed by Weatherhead & Stitt.

results.title: One for the road
results.creator_credit: Dennis A. Hill and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: A few hours in the life of Bill Smith show why you should not mix drinking with driving. The affect of alcohol is illustrated with a model brain: although not drunk Smith’s brain power was sufficiently impaired to cause a fatal accident.

results.title: Once Upon a Cheese
results.creator_credit: John Richardson, Kestrel Film Productions and Hugh Stuckey
results.brief_description: A light-hearted look at the cheese industry in Australia today. Shows how cheese is made by a fully automated process. Points out that special factories have been set up to produce cheddar. Lists the different types of cheeses - all of which are now available in Australia. Touches upon the varieties to be used with wines and beer, in cooking and how to store cheese at home.

results.title: On time
results.creator_credit: Victorian Railways, Eric Thompson and Department of the Interior
results.brief_description: More than 100,000 train passengers pass through the gates at Flinders Street Station, Melbourne each day. Control of passenger and freight trains in and out of the station on time is a masterpiece of precision planning.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian Railways, Eric Thompson and Department of the Interior

results.title: On the ball (1st Version)
results.brief_description: A humorous commentary on the game of Australian football. Go there, see it all. The screams, the advice, friendly admonitions. An analysis of the various aspects of Australian Rules Football spectatorship.

results.title: Om and Prom from Cambodia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “My Friends”.
A day in the life of two Cambodian boys. Shows them at school, at play, at home and working in the rice fields. They ride on elephants to the ruins of Angkor where they see the age-old ritual of the beautiful palace dancers.

results.title: Nullarbor hideout
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Tim Burstall, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The adventures of a group of children living at Cook on the Nullarbor Plain. They discover a swimming pool in a limestone cave and make the cave their hide-out. The children become involved with kangaroo shooters who are wanted by police for car stealing. Cast includes Tom Burstall, Betty Burstall, David Crocker, Frances Hatham, Marcus Skipper.

results.title: Not to lose you my language: bilingual education in the Northern Territory = Wangka walytjalampa titu ngaranytjaku
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Malcolm Otton, Timothy Read and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Gives an impression of the day-to-day operation of the Aboriginal bilingual program in three widely separated schools in the Northern Territory: Milingimbi, Yuendumu and the outstation of Yayayi.

results.title: Not by choice
results.creator_credit: Max Lemon, Douglas White and Double Crown
results.brief_description: A glimpse of Sydney’s soup-kitchens and the down-and-outs for whom they provide meals. This documentary film gives a glimpse of the institutions and of the lives of the men they assist. Its frankly emotional approach avoids any attempt to explain causes or to offer solutions. In fact it suggests that strong personal pride is characteristic of these men, and would prohibit any easy solution.
